label: Letter from George Weedon to Nathanael Greene
description: Letter from George Weedon to Nathanael Greene regarding the British evacuation of ‘Charles Towne’ and the plans of Continental Army officers for the end of the war.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
[George Weedon to Nathanael Greene
November 6, 1782
[RvW Box 2 Folder 43; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Fredericksburg Novr. 6th. 1782
My dear Genl. [General]
I am honored with Your agreeable
fav - 1st Ultimo for which You have my thanks.
Nothing is more flattering than the prospect now
before us, and I trust a few Months more will put
an End to our Military troubles, I am sure there
is not a Circumstance in life that would afford me
so much Satisfaction, and I think I can answer
for the rest of Our Brother Officers who have shared
with us in Adversity, and have now nothing to re-
-tire on but light hearth, and thin Breaches.
however the reflection of Independence compen-
-sates for every thing and I hope none will give
ground till that is happily accomplished. –
I am fully apprised how necessary it is
for us to be jealous of every ministerial measure,
Giving up the American Sun, is a bitter Pill
to them but is must be Swallowed, in the mean
time Wisdom tells us to Continue the watch [and]
not to be deluded by British Chicanerie [sic], they 
will try every Intelligence however I hope it is
now too late, Our Alliances strengthen us their
their power diminishes.
The Evacuation of Charles Town I had
set down as on the 1st. of October, the measure
I was sure would take place this fall, For
when the commons confess “That the Reble [sic]
Genl. [General] Green[e] had so changed the face of war
in that Quarter, that it now became a con-
-sideration of a future day”, What other
[End Page 1]
Idea could an Enthusiast have, who has ever
conceived himself inspired with a true knowledge
of the Event of your Operations? –
The Refugees I consider as an offspring of
Miltons fallen Tribe – I fancy however they
want a Moloch to stand up and afford conso-
-lation by New projects in War. They like
their Breathern [sic] are kicked out of the land of
Bliss, let them now Grovell [sic] in dirst [dirt] for past
offences, I pitty [sic] them not. –
New York is not as Yet Evacuated
nor do I think it will shortly, perhaps they
may draw their forces to that point for a time
with a Vein to serve as an object in negotiations.
Your wishes being compleat [sic] affords Your
Friends no small satisfaction, Our knowledge
of each other makes me thus free in language
And may I assure You my dear General, no
period in this war more interested my feelings
than that in which You Assumed the Deranged
and desperate command of the Southern
Department, and I bless my Stars for my
Friends success, return now with laurels
You ware [wear] them justly. –
You cant conceive how happy You
have made my little Family by informing
Mrs Green[e] keeps her health. Mrs Weedon bids
me tell You boath [sic], she will have plentiful
Dishes served up with frollicks for Your re-
-ception, I wish You would hurry on and
spend the Winter with us, for notwithstanding
You have have been so Accustomed of late
[End Page 2]
to reducing  Posts, be assured the two Gunner
Redoubt[s] in Fredericksburg, will from Inclination
give You a warm reception, - I shall lay in 
Plentiful Magazines of Hogg meat [and] Homoney [sic], 
Peach [and] Rye Liqr therefore advance whenever
You please. -   Washington [and] Lee have secured 
for themselves Admirable Quarters. It gives me
the highest satisfaction to hear of a Continental's 
sitting down with a plentiful supply of corn,
wine, [and] Oil, The latter of those Gentlemen has
been busy in making his Domistick Arrangements,
and has Pitched his Tent at Stratford in the
Northward Neck, about 20 miles from hence.
I shall tell him of his neglect the first time I see
him.      Be so obliging as to present my respect
to Burnett, let him know Mr. Burnman [?] has recd.
the letters he inclosed under Cover of his last fav.r
And I have this moment an Oportunity [sic] of sending
him his second.  Katty joines [sic] me to love to
you and lady, Believe me
Yours affectionately
G [George] Weedon 
[End Page 3]
[Endorsed:]  General Weeden [Weedon]
Nov [November] 6th 1782
[?]           X
146
[End Page 4]
